title: Libro de Investigaciones
text:
Estructura del Libro
Este libro está organizado con Quarto, donde cada capítulo presenta un artículo científico completo:

Capítulo 1: La Palma Seismicity 2021
Análisis de enjambres de terremotos en relación con la erupción de 2021
En septiembre de 2021, un salto significativo en la actividad sísmica en la isla de La Palma (Islas Canarias, España) señaló el comienzo de una crisis volcánica. Este estudio analiza los datos de terremotos recopilados y publicados por el Instituto Geográfico Nacional (IGN), revelando sismicidad que se origina en dos profundidades distintas.

Fuente: GitHub Repository
Enfoque: Análisis de datos sísmicos y modelado de reservorios magmáticos



Capítulo 2: Evaluating the Transfer of Information in Phase Retrieval STEM Techniques
Algoritmos ptychográficos directos para microscopía electrónica de transmisión de barrido
Este estudio evalúa métodos de recuperación de fase en microscopía electrónica de transmisión de barrido (STEM), analizando técnicas como imágenes del centro de masa, STEM de campo brillante corregido por inclinación y métodos ptychográficos directos.

Fuente: Elemental Microscopy
Enfoque: Desarrollo de algoritmos ptychográficos directos mejorados
crumbs: Bienvenido

title: Libro de Investigaciones
text:
Arquitectura del Proyecto
Esta implementación en Quarto ofrece:

✅ Estabilidad garantizada: Servidor web confiable y funcional
✅ Navegación fluida: Enlaces internos que funcionan correctamente
✅ Formato científico: Soporte nativo para ecuaciones, referencias y figuras
✅ Exports múltiples: HTML interactivo y PDF profesional
✅ Live preview: Actualización automática durante edición
✅ Mantenimiento sencillo: Configuración simple y robusta
crumbs: Bienvenido

title: Libro de Investigaciones
text:
Navegación
Utiliza la navegación lateral o los enlaces de capítulos para explorar los diferentes estudios de investigación incluidos en este libro.
crumbs: Bienvenido

title: La Palma Earthquakes: Seismic Analysis of Volcanic Activity
text:
Abstract
This study analyzes seismic activity associated with the 2021 La Palma volcanic eruption to investigate evidence for proposed multi-reservoir magma systems. Using earthquake data from the Instituto Geográfico Nacional, we examine spatial and temporal patterns of seismicity to validate theoretical models of magma storage and transport. Our analysis of 5,465 seismic events reveals distinct clustering at shallow (10-15 km) and deep (30-40 km) depths, providing strong evidence for both crustal and mantle magma reservoirs feeding the Cumbre Vieja volcanic system.
crumbs: 1  La Palma Earthquakes: Seismic Analysis of Volcanic Activity

title: 1  La Palma Earthquakes: Seismic Analysis of Volcanic Activity
text:
2.1 Introduction
La Palma, situated in the westernmost region of the Canary Islands archipelago, represents one of Earth’s most active volcanic systems. Located approximately 100 km from the African coast, this Spanish territory exemplifies ongoing oceanic island formation processes. The island’s geological evolution has been dominated by multiple phases of volcanism, with the Cumbre Vieja volcanic ridge—a north-south oriented structure comprising the southern half of the island—representing the most recent and currently active phase.
Understanding volcanic earthquake patterns is crucial for eruption forecasting and hazard assessment. The 2021 eruption of Cumbre Vieja provided an exceptional opportunity to study real-time seismic signatures associated with magma movement through proposed multi-reservoir systems.
crumbs: 1  La Palma Earthquakes: Seismic Analysis of Volcanic Activity

title: 1  La Palma Earthquakes: Seismic Analysis of Volcanic Activity
text:
2.4 Dataset
The earthquake dataset used in our analysis was generated from the IGN web portal - this is public data released under a permissive license. Data was recorded using a network of seismic monitoring stations on the island. A web scraping script was developed to pull data into a machine-readable form for analysis.
crumbs: 1  La Palma Earthquakes: Seismic Analysis of Volcanic Activity

title: 1  La Palma Earthquakes: Seismic Analysis of Volcanic Activity
text:
2.5 Results
The dataset was loaded and filtered down to La Palma events only. This results in 5465 data points which were then visualized to understand their distributions spatially, by depth, by magnitude and in time.
From our analysis, we can see 3 different systems in play:

Shallow earthquake swarm leading up to the eruption on 19th September, related to significant surface deformation and shallow magma intrusion.
Continuous shallow seismicity started at 10-15km corresponding to magma movement in the crustal reservoir after the eruption.
High magnitude events begin occurring at 30-40km depths corresponding to changes in the mantle reservoir. These are continuous but occur with a lower frequency than in the crustal reservoir.
crumbs: 1  La Palma Earthquakes: Seismic Analysis of Volcanic Activity

title: 1  La Palma Earthquakes: Seismic Analysis of Volcanic Activity
text:
2.6 Conclusions
From the analysis of the earthquake data collected and published by IGN for the period of 11 September through to 9 November 2021, visualization of the earthquake events at different depths appears to confirm the presence of both mantle and crustal reservoirs as proposed in previous studies.
The two-reservoir model is supported by: - Distinct depth clustering of seismic events - Temporal correlation with volcanic activity phases
- Magnitude distribution patterns
This analysis demonstrates the value of continuous seismic monitoring for understanding volcanic systems and improving eruption forecasting capabilities.
crumbs: 1  La Palma Earthquakes: Seismic Analysis of Volcanic Activity

title: 1  La Palma Earthquakes: Seismic Analysis of Volcanic Activity
text:
2.7 Data Availability
A web scraping script was developed to pull data into a machine-readable form for analysis. The code and recently updated data are available on GitHub along with analysis notebooks and visualization tools.
crumbs: 1  La Palma Earthquakes: Seismic Analysis of Volcanic Activity

title: 2  Evaluating Phase Retrieval STEM Techniques
text: 3 Evaluating Phase Retrieval STEM Techniques
crumbs: 2  Evaluating Phase Retrieval STEM Techniques

title: 2  Evaluating Phase Retrieval STEM Techniques
text:
3.2 Introduction
Phase retrieval in electron microscopy has become increasingly important for achieving atomic-resolution imaging. STEM techniques offer unique advantages for phase retrieval due to their focused probe geometry and flexible detector configurations.
crumbs: 2  Evaluating Phase Retrieval STEM Techniques

title: 2  Evaluating Phase Retrieval STEM Techniques
text:
3.3 Phase Retrieval Methods in STEM

3.3.1 Center-of-Mass Imaging
Center-of-mass (COM) imaging utilizes the deflection of the electron beam to reconstruct phase information. The method is based on measuring the shift in the diffraction pattern centroid.


3.3.2 Tilt-Corrected Bright-Field STEM
This technique corrects for aberrations by analyzing the intensity variations in bright-field STEM images acquired at different tilt conditions.


3.3.3 Direct Ptychographic Methods
Direct ptychography reconstructs both the object and probe simultaneously from overlapping diffraction patterns, offering superior resolution and sensitivity.
crumbs: 2  Evaluating Phase Retrieval STEM Techniques

title: 2  Evaluating Phase Retrieval STEM Techniques
text:
3.4 Methodology

3.4.1 Analytical Framework
We developed a comprehensive framework to evaluate the information transfer capabilities of each technique using:

Contrast Transfer Function (CTF) analysis
Spectral Signal-to-Noise Ratio (SSNR) calculations

Phase reconstruction fidelity metrics



3.4.2 Performance Metrics

3.4.2.1 Contrast Transfer Function (CTF)
The CTF describes how different spatial frequencies are transferred from the object to the image:
\[
CTF(k) = \sin(\chi(k))
\]
where \(\chi(k)\) is the aberration function.


3.4.2.2 Spectral Signal-to-Noise Ratio (SSNR)
SSNR quantifies the quality of phase information transfer:
\[
SSNR(k) = \frac{|F_{signal}(k)|^2}{|F_{noise}(k)|^2}
\]
crumbs: 2  Evaluating Phase Retrieval STEM Techniques

title: 2  Evaluating Phase Retrieval STEM Techniques
text:
3.5 Results

3.5.1 Contrast Transfer Function Analysis
Our CTF analysis reveals that direct ptychographic methods provide the most uniform information transfer across all spatial frequencies.


3.5.2 Signal-to-Noise Ratio Analysis
SSNR calculations demonstrate that:

Center-of-mass imaging excels at low spatial frequencies
Tilt-corrected bright-field STEM offers balanced performance
Direct ptychographic methods achieve superior high-frequency performance



3.5.3 Impact of Experimental Parameters
Key factors affecting performance include:

Scan sampling effects: Higher sampling improves reconstruction quality
Aberration sensitivity: Direct methods are more robust to aberrations
Detector geometry: Optimization critical for all techniques
crumbs: 2  Evaluating Phase Retrieval STEM Techniques

title: 2  Evaluating Phase Retrieval STEM Techniques
text:
3.6 Discussion

3.6.1 Advantages of SSNR Metrics
SSNR provides a more comprehensive evaluation than traditional CTF analysis by:

Incorporating noise characteristics
Accounting for experimental conditions
Enabling quantitative comparisons



3.6.2 Practical Implications

3.6.2.1 Method Selection Guidelines

For routine imaging: Center-of-mass techniques offer simplicity
For high-resolution work: Direct ptychographic methods preferred
For specific applications: Tilt-corrected methods provide balanced approach



3.6.2.2 Experimental Optimization
Optimal performance requires careful consideration of: - Probe conditions and aberrations - Detector design and positioning
- Scan parameters and sampling - Data acquisition strategies
crumbs: 2  Evaluating Phase Retrieval STEM Techniques

title: 2  Evaluating Phase Retrieval STEM Techniques
text:
3.7 Conclusions
This comprehensive evaluation demonstrates that:

Direct ptychographic methods offer superior performance for high-resolution phase imaging
SSNR analysis provides valuable insights beyond traditional CTF evaluation
Method selection should consider specific experimental requirements and constraints
Experimental optimization is crucial for achieving optimal performance with any technique

Future directions include development of hybrid approaches combining the strengths of different techniques and real-time optimization algorithms for experimental parameters.
crumbs: 2  Evaluating Phase Retrieval STEM Techniques

title: 2  Evaluating Phase Retrieval STEM Techniques
text:
3.8 Acknowledgments
We acknowledge the computational resources provided by various research institutions and the valuable discussions with the electron microscopy community that informed this analysis.
crumbs: 2  Evaluating Phase Retrieval STEM Techniques

title: La Palma Earthquakes: Seismic Analysis of Volcanic Activity
text:
1.2 Historical Context and Volcanic Setting

Eruption History
The historical volcanic record of La Palma spans over five centuries, providing valuable insights into the long-term behavior of the Cumbre Vieja system. Since European colonization in the late 1400s, eight major eruptions have been documented, establishing patterns crucial for probabilistic hazard assessment.

Recent historic eruptions on La Palma


Name
Year




Current
2021


Teneguía
1971


Nambroque
1949


El Charco
1712


Volcán San Antonio
1677


Volcán San Martin
1646


Tajuya near El Paso
1585


Montaña Quemada
1492



This equates to an eruption on average every 79 years up until the 1971 event. The probability of a future eruption can be modeled by a Poisson distribution:
\[
p(x)=\frac{e^{-\lambda} \lambda^{x}}{x !}
\]
Where \(\lambda\) is the number of eruptions per year, \(\lambda=\frac{1}{79}\) in this case. The probability of a future eruption in the next \(t\) years can be calculated by:
\[
p_e = 1-\mathrm{e}^{-t \lambda}
\]
So following the 1971 eruption the probability of an eruption in the following 50 years — the period ending this year — was 0.469. After the event, the number of eruptions per year moves to \(\lambda=\frac{1}{75}\) and the probability of a further eruption within the next 50 years (2022-2071) rises to 0.487 and in the next 100 years, this rises again to 0.736.


Theoretical Framework: Multi-Reservoir Magma Systems
Previous geophysical and petrological investigations have proposed a conceptual model involving two primary magma storage zones beneath Cumbre Vieja:

Deep mantle reservoir (30-40 km depth): Primary magma storage and differentiation zone
Shallow crustal reservoir (10-20 km depth): Secondary storage feeding eruptions

This hierarchical system suggests that magma ascends from the deep reservoir, undergoes further processing in the shallow chamber, and eventually reaches the surface during eruptions. Seismic monitoring provides a unique opportunity to test this model through analysis of earthquake depth distributions and temporal patterns.
crumbs: 1  La Palma Earthquakes: Seismic Analysis of Volcanic Activity

title: 1  La Palma Earthquakes: Seismic Analysis of Volcanic Activity
text:
2.3 Objectives and Scope
This study aims to:

Analyze spatial patterns of seismic activity to identify reservoir locations
Examine temporal relationships between deep and shallow seismicity
Evaluate the multi-reservoir model using observational data
Contribute to improved eruption forecasting methodologies
crumbs: 1  La Palma Earthquakes: Seismic Analysis of Volcanic Activity

title: 2  Evaluating Phase Retrieval STEM Techniques
text:
3.1 Abstract
This study evaluates methods for phase retrieval in Scanning Transmission Electron Microscopy (STEM), analyzing techniques such as center-of-mass imaging, tilt-corrected bright-field STEM, and direct ptychographic methods.
crumbs: 2  Evaluating Phase Retrieval STEM Techniques

title: La Palma Earthquakes: Seismic Analysis of Volcanic Activity
text:
Methods and Data

Seismic Data Acquisition
Earthquake data were obtained from the Instituto Geográfico Nacional (IGN) web portal, representing publicly available information collected through a comprehensive network of seismic monitoring stations deployed across La Palma. The dataset encompasses the critical period from September 11 to November 9, 2021, capturing pre-eruptive, syn-eruptive, and post-eruptive phases.


Data Processing and Quality Control
Raw seismic catalogs were processed using automated web scraping protocols to ensure reproducibility and systematic data collection. Quality control measures included verification of event locations, magnitudes, and depth determinations.


Analytical Framework
Statistical analysis focused on: - Spatial distribution of hypocenters - Temporal evolution of seismic activity - Depth-magnitude relationships - Clustering analysis for reservoir identification
crumbs: 1  La Palma Earthquakes: Seismic Analysis of Volcanic Activity

title: La Palma Earthquakes: Seismic Analysis of Volcanic Activity
text:
Results and Analysis

Dataset Characteristics
Analysis of the complete IGN catalog yielded 5,465 seismic events specifically attributed to La Palma during the study period. These data were systematically analyzed across multiple dimensions: spatial distribution, temporal evolution, magnitude characteristics, and depth clustering patterns.


Evidence for Multi-Reservoir System
Our comprehensive analysis reveals three distinct seismic signatures that strongly support the proposed multi-reservoir magma system:

1. Pre-Eruptive Shallow Swarm Activity
Intense earthquake swarms occurred in the shallow subsurface (< 10 km depth) during the weeks preceding the September 19th eruption onset. This activity correlates with significant surface deformation measurements and indicates shallow magma intrusion processes.


2. Syn- and Post-Eruptive Crustal Reservoir Activity
Following eruption initiation, continuous moderate-magnitude seismicity established at 10-15 km depth, consistent with ongoing magma movement within the proposed shallow crustal reservoir. This persistent activity suggests active magma storage and transport processes.


3. Deep Mantle Reservoir Signatures
High-magnitude seismic events (M > 4.0) occurred systematically at 30-40 km depths throughout the study period. These deeper events, while less frequent than shallow activity, demonstrate continuous activity within the proposed deep mantle reservoir system.
crumbs: 1  La Palma Earthquakes: Seismic Analysis of Volcanic Activity

title: La Palma Earthquakes: Seismic Analysis of Volcanic Activity
text:
Discussion

Validation of Multi-Reservoir Models
The seismic evidence presented strongly validates theoretical multi-reservoir magma storage models previously proposed for Cumbre Vieja. The bimodal depth distribution of earthquakes, with distinct clustering at shallow (10-15 km) and deep (30-40 km) levels, provides compelling observational support for hierarchical magma storage systems.


Implications for Volcanic Hazard Assessment
Understanding magma reservoir architecture has direct implications for eruption forecasting:

Deep reservoir monitoring: High-magnitude events at mantle depths may serve as long-term eruption precursors
Shallow reservoir dynamics: Swarm activity in the crustal reservoir provides short-term eruption warnings
System connectivity: Temporal relationships between deep and shallow activity indicate reservoir interaction



Methodological Advances
This study demonstrates the effectiveness of systematic seismic catalog analysis for validating geophysical models. The integration of spatial, temporal, and magnitude characteristics provides a robust framework for magma system characterization.
crumbs: 1  La Palma Earthquakes: Seismic Analysis of Volcanic Activity

title: La Palma Earthquakes: Seismic Analysis of Volcanic Activity
text:
Data Availability Statement
Seismic data were obtained from the Instituto Geográfico Nacional (IGN) public database. Data processing scripts, analysis notebooks, and visualization tools have been developed to ensure reproducibility and are available through institutional repositories. All methodological approaches follow open science principles to facilitate community validation and extension.
crumbs: 1  La Palma Earthquakes: Seismic Analysis of Volcanic Activity
